questions.neutral: You look like you've seen some things - rough day?

hobby.message: Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?
I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: It was... more complicated than usual at work.
I do origami sometimes, helps wait things out.
Noise outside lately makes it hard to focus.
People are louder now, after assemblies.
Rough enough that I needed to fold something precise at home.
I make origami out of scrap records. Keeps my hands busy, I guess.
Assemblies in the square below my window—hard to ignore now.
It interferes with the details. Some models take hours.
Just one of those days you can’t shake off.
I fold complex origami models—lately out of BCI printouts, actually.
It started as a way to wind down. Now it’s necessary.
Truth assemblies set up right below me. The voices, the tension… it seeps in.
Tried making a crane last night, but the creases wouldn’t line up.
Even the quietest hobby gets affected by what’s happening now.
Honestly, folding origami is what gets me through.
I use discarded system logs—turning something bureaucratic into something... quiet.
But with the assemblies in the square, every crease felt more urgent.
Neighbors argue about who should speak. Their voices carry right through the walls.
I tried folding a six-intersection tessellation last night.
Usually, it's meditative. Last night, I kept waiting for someone to ask what I was doing.
It’s strange—the city’s chaos pressing in on little paper models.
I’ve always folded origami. Started with bus tickets, then system waste—BCI logs, mostly.
It gives me... a way to process all the data without letting it haunt me.
When things got worse—assemblies outside, accusations everywhere—I folded more, even when my hands shook.
Last night, I used old compliance notices for cranes. Each fold felt heavier than the paper.
Growing up, I thought order meant safety. But now, I create quiet out of chaos, just for myself.
Noise outside makes the silence indoors sharper. It changes how the folds look, even the finished models.
Sometimes I wonder if any of this will be left after all this passes.
I almost left the cranes on my windowsill, part of me hoping someone else would notice.
hobby_answer: Yeah. I still fold sometimes.
Just paper, nothing special.
Hard to focus now with so much happening outside.
The new assemblies make it noisy, that’s all.
People stare more when you hold anything odd.
It helps. A bit.
Folding calms me down. Even if it’s just data scraps.
Truth assemblies outside my window keep breaking my concentration.
Sometimes I worry someone will ask why I collect records.
Everyone’s suspicious now. Even about paper.
Origami’s steadier than anything else lately.
I use system printouts, not that it matters much now.
The assemblies in the square make it hard to relax.
You hear testimonies through the wall. It sticks in your head.
People notice cranes on your window ledge. Some ask about them.
Last week, I folded while they were reading BCI logs outside.
Strange how a habit turns political these days.
It’s definitely better than meds. Keeps my mind from spiraling.
I started using old BCI dump paper. Symbolic, I guess.
The assemblies have taken over the whole square below me.
I listen to people sharing complaints, folding as if it helps them too.
Sometimes I wonder if the cranes make things worse. People notice.
A neighbor asked what data I’m hiding in them. Joking, but I’m not sure.
Used to fold for focus. Now it feels defiant somehow.
Some nights I fold until dawn, can’t switch off with all the noise.
Always been better than meds for me. Focus in the chaos.
I used to sneak company forms for paper. Now I just collect discards openly.
Funny, the same data that labeled us now becomes birds on my sill.
At the last assembly, I folded a crane with someone shouting about their lost job below.
Sometimes I worry my cranes mean the wrong thing. To the wrong people.
Honestly, folding lets me hide in plain sight, when everything else draws suspicion.
Last week, a security review team passed by my window three times.
I keep folding anyway. It’s habit. It’s hope. I don’t know.
Wouldn’t have believed paper animals could feel subversive, but these days, they do.
